segment.source: Lab 2, Classic-style deployment, uses command line tools in the Windows ADK to customize and deploy a Windows image.
segment.target: Lab 2, Classic-style deployment, uses command line tools in the Windows ADK to customize and deploy a Windows image.

segment.source: Lab 2 covers all the steps to customize and deploy a Windows image with optional steps for hardware configuration 1B and 2.
segment.target: Lab 2 covers all the steps to customize and deploy a Windows image with optional steps for hardware configuration 1B and 2.

segment.source: Lab 2a shows you how to continue customizing your image by adding Classic Windows applications.
segment.target: Lab 2a shows you how to continue customizing your image by adding Classic Windows applications.

segment.source: Lab 2b shows you how to service your custom image with Windows updates.
segment.target: Lab 2b shows you how to service your custom image with Windows updates.

segment.source: Customize and deploy a Windows image
segment.target: Customize and deploy a Windows image

segment.source: In this lab, you modify your images by adding and removing languages, drivers, and packages.
segment.target: In this lab, you modify your images by adding and removing languages, drivers, and packages.

segment.source: You can add a language, language components, and boot-critical drivers (such as storage drivers or video drivers) to the Windows image and the built-in recovery tools, as well as upgrade the edition, and set it to boot automatically to audit mode for factory-floor servicing.
segment.target: You can add a language, language components, and boot-critical drivers (such as storage drivers or video drivers) to the Windows image and the built-in recovery tools, as well as upgrade the edition, and set it to boot automatically to audit mode for factory-floor servicing.

segment.source: image: copying image files and deployment scripts
segment.target: image: copying image files and deployment scripts

segment.source: Step 1: Copy the base Windows image file
segment.target: Step 1: Copy the base Windows image file

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: Create a copy of the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: Create a copy of the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: For the purposes of this lab, use the base Windows 10 image file for either x64 or x86:
segment.target: For the purposes of this lab, use the base Windows 10 image file for either x64 or x86:

segment.source: This can take several minutes.
segment.target: This can take several minutes.

segment.source: Step 2: Mount the Windows image file
segment.target: Step 2: Mount the Windows image file

segment.source: Mount the Windows image.
segment.target: Mount the Windows image.

segment.source: The mounting process maps the contents of an image file to a location where you can view and modify the mounted image.
segment.target: The mounting process maps the contents of an image file to a location where you can view and modify the mounted image.

segment.source: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image and 1 is the index of the image that you want to use.
segment.target: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image and 1 is the index of the image that you want to use.

segment.source: This step can take several minutes.
segment.target: This step can take several minutes.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: If this command fails, make sure that you are using the Windows 10 version of DISM that is installed with the Windows ADK.
segment.target: If this command fails, make sure that you are using the Windows 10 version of DISM that is installed with the Windows ADK.

segment.source: If your technician PC uses Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7, use the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment to access the tools that are installed together with the Windows 10 version of the Windows ADK.
segment.target: If your technician PC uses Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7, use the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment to access the tools that are installed together with the Windows 10 version of the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Don’t mount images to protected folders, such as your UserDocuments folder.
segment.target: Don’t mount images to protected folders, such as your UserDocuments folder.

segment.source: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider temporarily disconnecting from the public network and disabling virus protection.
segment.target: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider temporarily disconnecting from the public network and disabling virus protection.

segment.source: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider running the commands from the Windows PE environment.
segment.target: If DISM processes are interrupted, consider running the commands from the Windows PE environment.

segment.source: Step 3: Mount the Windows RE image file
segment.target: Step 3: Mount the Windows RE image file

segment.source: Mount the Windows RE image file.
segment.target: Mount the Windows RE image file.

segment.source: The Windows RE image file is part of the Windows image.
segment.target: The Windows RE image file is part of the Windows image.

segment.source: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.
segment.target: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.

segment.source: This step can take several minutes.
segment.target: This step can take several minutes.

segment.source: Note We recommend that you update the Windows and Windows RE images at the same time, to help make sure that any necessary files are included in both images.
segment.target: Note We recommend that you update the Windows and Windows RE images at the same time, to help make sure that any necessary files are included in both images.

segment.source: Step 4: Add drivers to Windows
segment.target: Step 4: Add drivers to Windows

segment.source: Add any .inf-style drivers needed for your hardware.
segment.target: Add any .inf-style drivers needed for your hardware.

segment.source: where "C:DriversPnP.Media.V1media1.inf" is the base .inf file in your driver package.
segment.target: where "C:DriversPnP.Media.V1media1.inf" is the base .inf file in your driver package.

segment.source: Note For this section we’re adding /LogPath in case things go wrong –if there’s a problem with adding your driver, open this file to quickly check for errors.
segment.target: Note For this section we’re adding /LogPath in case things go wrong –if there’s a problem with adding your driver, open this file to quickly check for errors.

segment.source: To install all of the drivers from a folder and all its subfolders, point to the folder and use the /Recurse option.
segment.target: To install all of the drivers from a folder and all its subfolders, point to the folder and use the /Recurse option.

segment.source: Warning While /Recurse can be handy, it's easy to bloat your image with it.
segment.target: Warning While /Recurse can be handy, it's easy to bloat your image with it.

segment.source: Some driver packages include multiple .inf driver packages, which often share payload files from the same folder.
segment.target: Some driver packages include multiple .inf driver packages, which often share payload files from the same folder.

segment.source: During installation, each .inf driver package is expanded into a separate folder, each with a copy of the payload files.
segment.target: During installation, each .inf driver package is expanded into a separate folder, each with a copy of the payload files.

segment.source: We've seen cases where a popular driver in a 900MB folder added 10GB to images when added with the /Recurse option.
segment.target: We've seen cases where a popular driver in a 900MB folder added 10GB to images when added with the /Recurse option.

segment.source: Verify that the driver is part of the image:
segment.target: Verify that the driver is part of the image:

segment.source: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the driver.
segment.target: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the driver.

segment.source: If these drivers are critical for the hardware to boot, add them to the Windows RE image, too.
segment.target: If these drivers are critical for the hardware to boot, add them to the Windows RE image, too.

segment.source: Optional: You can remove any .inf drivers from previous tests:
segment.target: Optional: You can remove any .inf drivers from previous tests:

segment.source: For any setup.exe-style drivers, you’ll need to install these later in audit mode, or use a provisioning package.
segment.target: For any setup.exe-style drivers, you’ll need to install these later in audit mode, or use a provisioning package.

segment.source: Later in this section, we’ll show you how to set up the PC to boot into audit mode automatically.
segment.target: Later in this section, we’ll show you how to set up the PC to boot into audit mode automatically.

segment.source: In Windows 10, OEMs can modify the default Start layout and specify the layout of the OEM tiles by creating a LayoutModification.xml file and placing this file in the correct system location.
segment.target: In Windows 10, OEMs can modify the default Start layout and specify the layout of the OEM tiles by creating a LayoutModification.xml file and placing this file in the correct system location.

segment.source: Step 5: Add the files you need to modify the Start layout (Optional)
segment.target: Step 5: Add the files you need to modify the Start layout (Optional)

segment.source: Create a LayoutModification.xml file.
segment.target: Create a LayoutModification.xml file.

segment.source: For this lab, you can use the sample from the Pre-Requesites document.
segment.target: For this lab, you can use the sample from the Pre-Requesites document.

segment.source: The sample will pin Office, OneNote and Reader to Start if they are preloaded on the device (Step 8).
segment.target: The sample will pin Office, OneNote and Reader to Start if they are preloaded on the device (Step 8).

segment.source: To create your own LayoutModification.xml file by using an XML editor, see the Sample scripts.
segment.target: To create your own LayoutModification.xml file by using an XML editor, see the Sample scripts.

segment.source: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.
segment.target: Add your LayoutModification.xml file to the Windows image.

segment.source: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.
segment.target: You’ll need to put the file in the following specific location before first boot.

segment.source: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.
segment.target: If the file exists, you should replace the LayoutModification.XML that is already included in the image.

segment.source: If you pinned tiles that require .url or .lnk files, add the files to the following legacy Start Menu directories:
segment.target: If you pinned tiles that require .url or .lnk files, add the files to the following legacy Start Menu directories:

segment.source: %APPDATA%MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms
segment.target: %APPDATA%MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms

segment.source: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms
segment.target: %ALLUSERSPROFILE%MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms

segment.source: Note The Start layout can be lost if the user resets their PC with the built-in recovery tools.
segment.target: Note The Start layout can be lost if the user resets their PC with the built-in recovery tools.

segment.source: You'll learn how to make sure these settings stay on the device in Sample scripts.
segment.target: You'll learn how to make sure these settings stay on the device in Sample scripts.

segment.source: Add or change languages and Cortana features on demand (Optional)
segment.target: Add or change languages and Cortana features on demand (Optional)

segment.source: Note Skip this section for hardware configuration 1.
segment.target: Note Skip this section for hardware configuration 1.

segment.source: Always use language packs and Features-On-Demand (FOD) packages that match the language and platform of the Windows image.
segment.target: Always use language packs and Features-On-Demand (FOD) packages that match the language and platform of the Windows image.

segment.source: Features on demand (FODs) are Windows feature packages that can be added at any time.
segment.target: Features on demand (FODs) are Windows feature packages that can be added at any time.

segment.source: When a user needs a new feature, they can request the feature package from Windows Update.
segment.target: When a user needs a new feature, they can request the feature package from Windows Update.

segment.source: OEMs can preinstall these features to enable them on their devices out of the box.
segment.target: OEMs can preinstall these features to enable them on their devices out of the box.

segment.source: Common features include language resources like handwriting recognition.
segment.target: Common features include language resources like handwriting recognition.

segment.source: Some of these features are required to enable full Cortana functionality.
segment.target: Some of these features are required to enable full Cortana functionality.

segment.source: The following table shows the types of language packages and components available for Windows 10:
segment.target: The following table shows the types of language packages and components available for Windows 10:

segment.source: Component
segment.target: Component

segment.source: Sample file name
segment.target: Sample file name

segment.source: Dependencies
segment.target: Dependencies

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Language pack
segment.target: Language pack

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.
segment.target: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.

segment.source: Language interface pack
segment.target: Language interface pack

segment.source: Requires a specific fully-localized or partially-localized language pack.
segment.target: Requires a specific fully-localized or partially-localized language pack.

segment.source: Example: ca-ES requires es-ES.
segment.target: Example: ca-ES requires es-ES.

segment.source: To learn more, see Available Language Packs for Windows.
segment.target: To learn more, see Available Language Packs for Windows.

segment.source: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.
segment.target: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: Spell checking, text prediction, word breaking, and hyphenation if available for the language.
segment.target: Spell checking, text prediction, word breaking, and hyphenation if available for the language.

segment.source: You must add this component before adding any of the following components.
segment.target: You must add this component before adding any of the following components.

segment.source: Fonts
segment.target: Fonts

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: Fonts.
segment.target: Fonts.

segment.source: Required for some regions to render text that appears in documents.
segment.target: Required for some regions to render text that appears in documents.

segment.source: Example, th-TH requires the Thai font pack.
segment.target: Example, th-TH requires the Thai font pack.

segment.source: To learn more, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).
segment.target: To learn more, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).

segment.source: Optical character recognition
segment.target: Optical character recognition

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Recognizes and outputs text in an image.
segment.target: Recognizes and outputs text in an image.

segment.source: Handwriting recognition
segment.target: Handwriting recognition

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Enables handwriting recognition for devices with pen input.
segment.target: Enables handwriting recognition for devices with pen input.

segment.source: Text-to-speech
segment.target: Text-to-speech

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Enables text to speech, used by Cortana and Narrator.
segment.target: Enables text to speech, used by Cortana and Narrator.

segment.source: Speech recognition
segment.target: Speech recognition

segment.source: Basic, Text-To-Speech recognition
segment.target: Basic, Text-To-Speech recognition

segment.source: Recognizes voice input, used by Cortana and Windows Speech Recognition.
segment.target: Recognizes voice input, used by Cortana and Windows Speech Recognition.

segment.source: Step 6: Add or change languages
segment.target: Step 6: Add or change languages

segment.source: Add languages, and Features On Demand to the Windows image.
segment.target: Add languages, and Features On Demand to the Windows image.

segment.source: For packages with dependencies, make sure you install the packages in order.
segment.target: For packages with dependencies, make sure you install the packages in order.

segment.source: For example, to enable Cortana, install: lp.cab, then –Basic, then –Fonts, then –TextToSpeech, and then –Speech, in this order.
segment.target: For example, to enable Cortana, install: lp.cab, then –Basic, then –Fonts, then –TextToSpeech, and then –Speech, in this order.

segment.source: If you’re not sure of the dependencies, it’s OK to put them all in the same folder, and then add them all using the same DISM /Add-Package command.
segment.target: If you’re not sure of the dependencies, it’s OK to put them all in the same folder, and then add them all using the same DISM /Add-Package command.

segment.source: Not every region has fonts or capability packs for every feature.
segment.target: Not every region has fonts or capability packs for every feature.

segment.target: For example:

segment.target: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the package.

segment.target: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the packages.

segment.target: Step 7: Remove the base language (only needed for non-English regions)

segment.source: To save space, you can remove English language components when deploying to non-English regions.
segment.target: To save space, you can remove English language components when deploying to non-English regions.

segment.source: You'll need to uninstall them in the reverse order from how you add them.
segment.target: You'll need to uninstall them in the reverse order from how you add them.

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the drive.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the drive.

segment.target: Verify that the language package is no longer part of the image:

segment.target: Verify that the language components are no longer part of the image:

segment.source: Remove the Windows RE optional components.
segment.target: Remove the Windows RE optional components.

segment.source: After removing, verify that they're no longer in the image.
segment.target: After removing, verify that they're no longer in the image.

segment.source: Known issue: If you've removed the English language pack, in Windows 10 Build 10240, you'll need to boot the image into audit mode, and use the command: to repair issues with Windows 32-bit apps.
segment.target: Known issue: If you've removed the English language pack, in Windows 10 Build 10240, you'll need to boot the image into audit mode, and use the command: to repair issues with Windows 32-bit apps.

segment.source: For an example of how to do this with a script, see Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts.
segment.target: For an example of how to do this with a script, see Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts.

segment.source: Step 8: Reinstall inbox apps (required whenever adding languages)
segment.target: Step 8: Reinstall inbox apps (required whenever adding languages)

segment.source: Remove the existing inbox apps.
segment.target: Remove the existing inbox apps.

segment.source: (This step is not required if you're using Universal apps obtained after August 18, 2015).
segment.target: (This step is not required if you're using Universal apps obtained after August 18, 2015).

segment.source: The following example shows you how to remove the Get Started inbox app.
segment.target: The following example shows you how to remove the Get Started inbox app.

segment.source: Repeat these steps for each of the inbox apps (with the exception of AppConnector) by substituting the appropriate package.
segment.target: Repeat these steps for each of the inbox apps (with the exception of AppConnector) by substituting the appropriate package.

segment.source: Note To remove all of the apps at once, open a command prompt as an Administrator, navigate to the image folder, and run the sample script: “Removeappsinofflineimage.cmd” from the Sample scripts.
segment.target: Note To remove all of the apps at once, open a command prompt as an Administrator, navigate to the image folder, and run the sample script: “Removeappsinofflineimage.cmd” from the Sample scripts.

segment.source: Re-install the apps.
segment.target: Re-install the apps.

segment.source: The following example shows you how to reinstall the Get Started inbox app.
segment.target: The following example shows you how to reinstall the Get Started inbox app.

segment.source: Repeat these steps for each of the inbox apps (with the exception of AppConnector) by substituting the appropriate package.
segment.target: Repeat these steps for each of the inbox apps (with the exception of AppConnector) by substituting the appropriate package.

segment.source: Step 9: Add Windows Universal apps or Windows 8.1 Store apps (Optional)
segment.target: Step 9: Add Windows Universal apps or Windows 8.1 Store apps (Optional)

segment.source: You can add Windows Universal apps and Windows 8.1 Store apps to your image by using DISM.
segment.target: You can add Windows Universal apps and Windows 8.1 Store apps to your image by using DISM.

segment.source: In this example, you will preinstall Office, OneNote, and Windows Reader 8.1.
segment.target: In this example, you will preinstall Office, OneNote, and Windows Reader 8.1.

segment.source: Skip this step for hardware configuration 1.
segment.target: Skip this step for hardware configuration 1.

segment.source: Add the AppX package.
segment.target: Add the AppX package.

segment.source: Where the PackagePath points to the app bundle package.
segment.target: Where the PackagePath points to the app bundle package.

segment.source: Repeat the DISM command for the OneNote, Reader, Word and PowerPoint preview app bundle packages.
segment.target: Repeat the DISM command for the OneNote, Reader, Word and PowerPoint preview app bundle packages.

segment.source: If the PC runs into trouble, your users may not be able to read/understand the recovery screens unless you add the appropriate language resources into the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).
segment.target: If the PC runs into trouble, your users may not be able to read/understand the recovery screens unless you add the appropriate language resources into the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).

segment.source: Whenever possible, try to add and remove languages in Windows RE at the same time that you add and remove them in your Windows image to ensure a consistent recovery experience.
segment.target: Whenever possible, try to add and remove languages in Windows RE at the same time that you add and remove them in your Windows image to ensure a consistent recovery experience.

segment.source: (This isn’t always possible, as not all languages have Windows RE equivalents.)
segment.target: (This isn’t always possible, as not all languages have Windows RE equivalents.)

segment.source: Step 10: Add languages to the recovery environment (highly recommended when adding languages)
segment.target: Step 10: Add languages to the recovery environment (highly recommended when adding languages)

segment.source: Add languages.
segment.target: Add languages.

segment.source: These languages are included with the Windows ADK.
segment.target: These languages are included with the Windows ADK.

segment.source: You must use a matching version of the Windows ADK to service the Windows RE image.
segment.target: You must use a matching version of the Windows ADK to service the Windows RE image.

segment.source: Note Windows RE now requires the WinPE-HTA package, this is new for Windows 10.
segment.target: Note Windows RE now requires the WinPE-HTA package, this is new for Windows 10.

segment.source: Note The WinPE-WiFi-Package is not language-specific and does not need to be added when adding other languages.
segment.target: Note The WinPE-WiFi-Package is not language-specific and does not need to be added when adding other languages.

segment.source: This is new for Windows 10.
segment.target: This is new for Windows 10.

segment.source: Set the default recovery language to match the preferred language for your customers.
segment.target: Set the default recovery language to match the preferred language for your customers.

segment.source: Optional: Remove languages from Windows RE (only needed for non-English regions)
segment.target: Optional: Remove languages from Windows RE (only needed for non-English regions)

segment.source: When you remove languages from Windows, remove them from Windows RE to save space.
segment.target: When you remove languages from Windows, remove them from Windows RE to save space.

segment.source: You can either use the /PackagePath switch (which requires a matching version of Windows and the Windows ADK) or the /PackageName switch (which requires identifying the package including the version number).
segment.target: You can either use the /PackagePath switch (which requires a matching version of Windows and the Windows ADK) or the /PackageName switch (which requires identifying the package including the version number).

segment.source: Step 11: Upgrade the edition from Core to Pro (Optional)
segment.target: Step 11: Upgrade the edition from Core to Pro (Optional)

segment.source: Use this procedure to upgrade the edition.
segment.target: Use this procedure to upgrade the edition.

segment.source: You cannot set a Windows image to a lower edition.
segment.target: You cannot set a Windows image to a lower edition.

segment.source: You should not use this procedure on an image that has already been changed to a higher edition.
segment.target: You should not use this procedure on an image that has already been changed to a higher edition.

segment.source: Determine what images you can upgrade the image to: Note the edition IDs available.
segment.target: Determine what images you can upgrade the image to: Note the edition IDs available.

segment.source: Upgrade the edition.
segment.target: Upgrade the edition.

segment.source: Step 12: Unmount the images
segment.target: Step 12: Unmount the images

segment.source: Close all applications that might access files from the image.
segment.target: Close all applications that might access files from the image.

segment.source: Commit the changes and unmount the Windows RE image:
segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the Windows RE image:

segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.

segment.source: This process can take a few minutes.
segment.target: This process can take a few minutes.

segment.source: Make a backup copy of the updated Windows RE image (optional).
segment.target: Make a backup copy of the updated Windows RE image (optional).

segment.source: This can help you save your work in case the Windows image gets corrupted.
segment.target: This can help you save your work in case the Windows image gets corrupted.

segment.source: When prompted, specify F for file.
segment.target: When prompted, specify F for file.

segment.source: Note This lab assumes you’d rather keep winre.wim inside of install.wim to keep your languages and drivers in sync.
segment.target: Note This lab assumes you’d rather keep winre.wim inside of install.wim to keep your languages and drivers in sync.

segment.source: If you’d like to save a bit of time on the factory floor, and if you’re OK managing these images separately, you may prefer to remove winre.wim from the image and apply it separately.
segment.target: If you’d like to save a bit of time on the factory floor, and if you’re OK managing these images separately, you may prefer to remove winre.wim from the image and apply it separately.

segment.source: Check the new size of the Windows RE image.
segment.target: Check the new size of the Windows RE image.

segment.source: If the size of the partition is greater than 524,288,000 bytes, convert the file size into megabytes, add free space, and modify the deployment script: CreatePartitions-Firmware.txt with the new value.
segment.target: If the size of the partition is greater than 524,288,000 bytes, convert the file size into megabytes, add free space, and modify the deployment script: CreatePartitions-Firmware.txt with the new value.

segment.source: To learn more about free space recommendations, see UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions.
segment.target: To learn more about free space recommendations, see UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions.

segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the Windows image:

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.

segment.source: This process may take several minutes.
segment.target: This process may take several minutes.

segment.source: Step 13: Copy the image and deployment scripts to a USB key
segment.target: Step 13: Copy the image and deployment scripts to a USB key

segment.source: Plug in the Windows PE USB key and note the drive location, for example, D:.
segment.target: Plug in the Windows PE USB key and note the drive location, for example, D:.

segment.source: Copy the image and the premade deployment scripts to a USB key, for example:
segment.target: Copy the image and the premade deployment scripts to a USB key, for example:

segment.source: Note If the Windows PE key doesn't have enough space, copy both the image and scripts to another USB key.
segment.target: Note If the Windows PE key doesn't have enough space, copy both the image and scripts to another USB key.

segment.source: Note If your image is greater than 4GB, you may need to preformat the USB key using the NTFS file format.
segment.target: Note If your image is greater than 4GB, you may need to preformat the USB key using the NTFS file format.

segment.source: Step 14: Apply Windows images using a script
segment.target: Step 14: Apply Windows images using a script

segment.source: Use deployment scripts to apply a newly-captured image onto a test device.
segment.target: Use deployment scripts to apply a newly-captured image onto a test device.

segment.source: These scripts set up the hard drive partitions and add the files from the Windows image to the partitions.
segment.target: These scripts set up the hard drive partitions and add the files from the Windows image to the partitions.

segment.source: Note In Windows 10, we've changed the partition layout.
segment.target: Note In Windows 10, we've changed the partition layout.

segment.source: While we still use a separate recovery tools image, Windows no longer needs a separate full-system recovery image to use push-button reset features.
segment.target: While we still use a separate recovery tools image, Windows no longer needs a separate full-system recovery image to use push-button reset features.

segment.source: This can save several GB of drive space.
segment.target: This can save several GB of drive space.

segment.source: We're also using a smaller MSR partition (down from 128MB to 16MB).
segment.target: We're also using a smaller MSR partition (down from 128MB to 16MB).

segment.source: Note You can use the sample scripts for different device firmware types (the newer UEFI-based BIOS, or the legacy BIOS).
segment.target: Note You can use the sample scripts for different device firmware types (the newer UEFI-based BIOS, or the legacy BIOS).

segment.source: Some UEFI-based devices include support for the older legacy BIOS.
segment.target: Some UEFI-based devices include support for the older legacy BIOS.

segment.source: For more info, see UEFI Firmware.
segment.target: For more info, see UEFI Firmware.

segment.source: Step 15: Format and set up the hard drive partitions on the reference device
segment.target: Step 15: Format and set up the hard drive partitions on the reference device

segment.source: Boot the reference device to Windows PE using the Windows PE USB key.
segment.target: Boot the reference device to Windows PE using the Windows PE USB key.

segment.source: Find the drive letter of the USB key by using diskpart:
segment.target: Find the drive letter of the USB key by using diskpart:

segment.source: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D = USB flash drive.
segment.target: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D = USB flash drive.

segment.source: Format the primary hard drive, create the partitions, and apply the image by using the pre-made sample scripts.
segment.target: Format the primary hard drive, create the partitions, and apply the image by using the pre-made sample scripts.

segment.source: The script ApplyImage.bat relies on these other scripts to be placed in the same folder:
segment.target: The script ApplyImage.bat relies on these other scripts to be placed in the same folder:

segment.source: CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt
segment.target: CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt

segment.source: CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt
segment.target: CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt

segment.source: HideRecoveryPartitions-UEFI.txt
segment.target: HideRecoveryPartitions-UEFI.txt

segment.source: HideRecoveryPartitions-BIOS.txt:
segment.target: HideRecoveryPartitions-BIOS.txt:

segment.source: You can download the scripts from the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: You can download the scripts from the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: where D is the drive letter of the USB flash drive.
segment.target: where D is the drive letter of the USB flash drive.

segment.source: When prompted by the script:
segment.target: When prompted by the script:

segment.source: Press Y to format the drive
segment.target: Press Y to format the drive

segment.source: Press Y to select Compact OS, or N to select a non-compacted OS:
segment.target: Press Y to select Compact OS, or N to select a non-compacted OS:

segment.source: Y: Applies the image using Compact OS.
segment.target: Y: Applies the image using Compact OS.

segment.source: This is best for devices with solid-state drives and drives with limited free space.
segment.target: This is best for devices with solid-state drives and drives with limited free space.

segment.source: Use this for hardware configuration 1 and 2.
segment.target: Use this for hardware configuration 1 and 2.

segment.source: N: Applies the image as a fully-uncompressed image.
segment.target: N: Applies the image as a fully-uncompressed image.

segment.source: This is best for high-performance devices or devices that use traditional hard drives with rotational media.
segment.target: This is best for high-performance devices or devices that use traditional hard drives with rotational media.

segment.source: Use this for hardware configuration 3.
segment.target: Use this for hardware configuration 3.

segment.source: Press N to indicate the image does not include extended attributes (EA).
segment.target: Press N to indicate the image does not include extended attributes (EA).

segment.source: The scripts apply the image to the drive, and then finish.
segment.target: The scripts apply the image to the drive, and then finish.

segment.source: Step 16: Restart the device
segment.target: Step 16: Restart the device

segment.source: Disconnect the USB flash drive and the external USB hard drive and type .
segment.target: Disconnect the USB flash drive and the external USB hard drive and type .

segment.source: While you’re waiting for the preparation phase to complete, go back to your technician PC and continue with the lab.
segment.target: While you’re waiting for the preparation phase to complete, go back to your technician PC and continue with the lab.

segment.source: Warning Troubleshooting: If the device does not boot, turn on the device, and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu (for example, the Esc key).
segment.target: Warning Troubleshooting: If the device does not boot, turn on the device, and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu (for example, the Esc key).
